ReviewList.Text: This book covers a lot of ground in a very creative way.  However, I am extremely puzzled how the kindle version was distributed with typesetting issues associated with the Dirac bracket which make it difficult to read.  There was obviously no review of the electronic version.  Amazon should republish a correction ASAP.

This is a great book, but get a print copy as there are serious problems with the typesetting in the Kindle version.  Right and left brackets <> are shown as boxes in the main text(although they are correct in equations)  As the brackets are used for Dirac’s notation throughout the text, this typo is more than just an minor annoyance. Dirac's bra and kett notation is a major part of quantum mechanics and having them printed incorrectly means confusion. I am surprised that this slipped past proof reading. This really is too bad, I really enjoyed Dr Susskind's 1st book and his videos so much and was looking forward to this new book. I'm sorry that this excellent content is ruined by this error. Again, buy the print copy.
I downloaded the iPad version on 3/14/14 and scanned for typography problems that others have noted. I see none! Maybe there has been an update.

Professor Susskind's lecture series on You Tube are very popular and he deserves our thanks for his efforts. It is also wonderful that there is an audience that wishes to learn these subjects. It is assumed that you know linear algebra and complex variables. If you have not had these subjects or need a refresher, you will have a better time with this book if you study or review these subjects. I would recommend the Cliff Quick Review of Linear Algebra by Leduc and Chapter 1 of Schaum's Complex Variables 2nd edition by Spiegel. They both have many worked out problems and the books are inexpensive.There are more expensive alternatives like Engineering Mathematics by Stroud or Shankar's Quantum Mechanics textbook which cover these areas.  Susskind makes heavy use of spin and the Pauli Matrices as a basic model for quantum mechanics. A similar approach was taken in Jordan's Quantum Mechanic in Simple Matrix Form published in the 1980s and available on Dover. Susskind is a good teacher and further simplifies the math, probabilities,  commutators, and operators to make the subject more easy to follow. The introductions to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, Schrodinger Equation, and Entaglement  are nicely done and are a good read. If you want to learn some concepts of basic Quantum Mechanics and are not adverse to the math described this book will fill that need. Learn or review the mentioned math first or you will be lost quickly. You need to know what a complex number is,why we need complex numbers, how to obtain a complex conjugate, and Euler's famous formula. Susskind covers this in three short pages which is unlikely to mean much to you if you do not remember or know the math.  It will also help to watch the lectures on You Tube.  The major flaw of the book is the excercises.  They range from easy to hard. The answers are not provided and the techniques for answering them should be fully worked out. This should have either been added as an appendix to the book or posted on the web. These excercises are meant to test and rewire your brain. They are important teaching tools but  most of us do not have teaching assistants to check our answers and help us when we are lost. What may be obvious to the teacher is frequently not obvious to the rest of us. I have taken off one star for not have a longer chapter on the math required. I have also taken off a star for the lack of answers (worked out would be even better) for the excercises.

I like the book. I can follow the discussion. But it's not for a lay reader. The ideal reader should have some background in classical mechanics (particularly the Hamiltonian formulation), some background in linear algebra, and not faint when he or she hears "Hilbert space." It would probably be a good companion text to a standard quantum mechanics text. There's definitely a niche for this book -- I don't know of any other book with this kind of careful yet verbose explanation. I particularly like the first example Susskind gives for the Schrodinger equation.

This book is pitched at a level for those who have calculus and perhaps already know some small corner of quantum theory, but want to retrace their steps a little and understand at a more basic level. Once you get this, you should be able to go on to more advanced texts and not worry about the physical basics and mathematical flow that sometimes seem a little obscure without a minimum such as this. A Ph.D. in chemistry was my foundation for reading this and even having studied the basics of nuclear magnetic resonance, it was nice to go back and fill in some of the conceptual holes in my understanding. I would have been able to use it back at undergraduate level to provide a foundation for what I wanted to go on and do.

Although this book claims to be written as an introduction to the subject, the fundamentals are explained poorly. Dirac's notation and his own personal vernacular in particular were unclear.  Dirac's notation, matrices and the bits of linear algebra were told to you, not explained in any way.  Youtube videos have done better.  Even having a sizable background in quantum physics things were left out or not explained that should have been.  If not for my prior knowledge, I doubt I could've read it.  There are better alternatives for self teaching.

This is the second part of Susskind's "The Theoretical Minimum" series, tackling the world of quantum mechanics.  I like the writing style and anecdotes.  The book starts gently but picks up quickly, leaving a casual reader behind.  The concepts are difficult.  The authors make them easier to understand, but by no means easy.  It is a serious book covering a serious subject... seriously.  Everyone who perseveres through the whole book will take away something; few readers will grasp everything - at least the first time through it.

I am a layman and am absolutely fascinated with particle physics.  I want to read everything on the subject including the math that is used to determine the state of space.  I wanted to see what the math looked like and what it took to figure out something so intriguing. It did meet my needs. Completely!

I really enjoy reading this book. By trade I am a medical doctor and my mathematics is only at high school level. Yet the authors are just brilliant in introducing essential concepts such as vector space, eigenvectors, eigenvalues, operators, and non-commutators in a way that a layperson can understand. These concepts are used to describe in mathematical and logical terms what measurements and observations signify. Building on these, the authors then employ similar method to explain what entanglement and Uncertainty Principle mean. The emphasis is on the logical structure of quantum mechanics and not philosophical speculation (section 7.10 maybe one exception). Schrödinger equation is also derived and explained. It should be noted that Volume 1 is presumed knowledge.

A wonderful book! I am returning to this field after many years of hiatus and am very pleased to have found this book. His pedagogical style of telling us what to expect, then telling us, then reiterate when necessary provides the clearest and easiest explanation yet of the fundamentals of Quantum Mechanics, especially of entanglement. His sprinkling of humorous remarks and obvious empathy with students makes this book a delight to read. After finishing this book I feel ready to tackle more complex applications and problem solving.

I thought I'd learn more about how sub-atomic particles acted and interacted. This book however, is more of a lesson in advanced mathematics which I am not capable of understanding. Thus, the book was essentially a bunch of gibberish and I wasted my money. I cannot recommend this book to the average reader.

This is a great book for someone who wants to learn some of the math behind quantum mechanics, to get a better understanding of the theory.  The book keeps the math to a moderately difficult level, and explains it in detail with mathematical interludes.  Even if you don't catch all the math, the book explains the key elements of quantum mechanics in a way anyone can understand.  Some physics and calculus background is necessary, but you don't have to be an expert to gain from this book.

I don't know about the average Joe, but for the student of physics, READ THIS BOOK. This treatment truly introduces the concepts of quantum mechanics instead of more classic "teach the math and the concepts will come later" crap. This book is absolutely fantastic, and as long as you go do some more staple problems like the hydrogen atom and learn some differential equations, you won't need to take an introductory course or read a more classic introductory text.

excellent primer on how QM describes a logical state space and not a physical state space -- something that none of the other books seem to care to explain. Lot of things become clear once that concept sinks in. Written in a nice friendly fashion, and yet in a rigourous mathematical way.
Susskind is awesome.  It has been many years since I intensely studied these subjects in college, and it is a pleasure to use his books to rekindle my interest and understanding.
For those who want the reason and not just the answer this book brings one great depth of topic. A truely wonderful book.
Even though it is a great book, it does need a companion book with solutions to the problems.
This subject was treated with care and precision. It was easy to read and understand.

Excellent! I enjoyed every page. Susskind eloquently explains basic quantum systems in great detail, providing in-depth explanations without a tinge of the patronising tone that is omnipotent in most non-rigorous physics texts. The second volume of 'The Theoretical Minimum' was a welcomed break from studies for my final exams and I thank both the authors for every second I spent pondering the concepts layed out within this fine book.
The best book yet  for a good basic education on Quantum Mechanics.
just right for 2nd and 3rd year science major
Great companion to Susskind's video lectures
makes a different concept approachable
It's a rigorous book but entirely tractable for a dilettante like me with some math skills (engineering major, now software developer).
as advertised
very insightful had to read it through twice.
Simply a very good book.  I learned a great deal about quantum mechanics. It isn't easy reading, for me, but it is enjoyable.
Very rare that there is a comprehensible book on the subject of quantum mechanics! I "think" I finally understand quantum mechanics
Considering the content, easy to read and understand. It does have equations, but everything necessary to understand them seem to be included.
Good Book
I was hoping that QM didn't have to hid behind Paul Dirac's bra and ket expressions and the trickery of manipulation resulting in coherence and decoherence, but I guess there is no alternatives.
Very deep book. Not for the casual reader. However it does cover the subject well. It involves too much math for me.
Yet to read it, but it looks good.
